results.content:
I've not even completed the course and I've learnt so much already!

I wanted to have a greater understanding of how MVC frameworks worked and this course is doing exactly that. I know how to use other frameworks like Laravel but used them without really understanding how or why they worked the way they do and sometimes those frameworks are very 'all-use' case scenarios and contain far more than what I really need. I wanted to have a lightweight framework I can use in small personal and freelance projects and this has helped me create that while understanding every aspect of it.

Everything is explained clearly and structured in a very logical way and I've already extended on what I've been taught so far with my own routing file and additional packages via composer which I wouldn't of been able to do before.

I got this course while it was on offer so I feel extremely lucky, but it's definitely worth the full price for those of you who are considering purchasing it or want a better understanding of MVC frameworks, Object Orientated Programming and PHP in general.

I'll be purchasing the follow up course (Build a Complete Registration and Login System using PHP MVC) to this to extend on my own framework even more!

results.content:
Overall, a great course.

I had just came out of Lynda.com, learning basic PHP, and a little bit of OOP as well. Eventually I took a full blown PHP OOP tutorial over there. From that, I dabbled in frameworks like CodeIgniter, understood it well, and then tried a little bit of Laravel. It was confusing to me, and I ended up taking a break from PHP for awhile.

When I came back I reviewed the basic PHP tutorial on Lynda.com, and saw how messy the code was including database and application logic in the same file. Since CodeIgniter had taught me the MVC framework and I enjoyed & had an understanding of it, I decided to find a tutorial that would teach me to craft my own, so I could dive into Laravel afterwards.

This course gave me everything I need to create a small project for my portfolio to showcase my abilities, and then get into Laravel in the future.

The only thing that I wish was explained a bit more were some of the OOP basics like when to use static methods and properties. Although, since experience with PHP was stated to be required I can understand why that information wasn't included, however one or two lectures on it may be helpful somewhere.

Thanks for the course! This really bridged a large gap in my understanding of classic PHP and PHP OOP/frameworks.

results.content: It's a very good course and teacher. One problem for me is, that the teacher only follows **exactly** one path. You put everything in one file each and you do camerCase or WhatWasThatNameCase, nothing else. I'm not that much a fan of these strict followings of one way..

response.content: Thank you for your review and feedback Udo! The reason we follow those strict coding standards is to make it easier for you and others to read your code. Most PHP developers follow these standards, which allows your code to be easily read by others, and more importantly, to be able to be reused by others too. You are of course free to use whatever naming standards you like, but for example if you store each class in a separate file, and name them using the PSR coding standards, you can use autoloading with Composer for no extra work at all. Thank you again for your feedback!
response.content_html: Thank you for your review and feedback Udo! The reason we follow those strict coding standards is to make it easier for you and others to read your code. Most PHP developers follow these standards, which allows your code to be easily read by others, and more importantly, to be able to be reused by others too. You are of course free to use whatever naming standards you like, but for example if you store each class in a separate file, and name them using the PSR coding standards, you can use autoloading with Composer for no extra work at all. Thank you again for your feedback!

response.content:
Hi Chad,

sorry you find my voice boring! I do try and speak as clearly as I can so that students whose first language isn't English can understand, but I do realise it can come across as monotone sometimes! I'm planning to update most of the videos soon so I'll try and be more expressive.

If you have any specific questions about any aspect of the framework, like how the router processes regular expressions, and where to put static files, please don't hesitate to ask! If you ask a question inside the course in the Q&A section I'll always answer, usually within 24 hours, normally quicker.

I hope that helps!

Thank you again for your feedback.

Best wishes,
Dave

results.content:
This is a great course and the instructor is easy to understand (linguistically). He enunciates his words in a way that makes the content stick. But even beyond this, it is a great course. I wasn't expecting so much of it to be dedicated to RegEx, but in retrospect I understand why it was.

It is easily five stars, but if someone were to ask me an area for improvement, I'd say an expansion of the router portion would have been helpful. That's one area I didn't metaphorically walk away from really understanding, and had to do some more digging.

But I highly recommend this course to anyone considering the implementation of MVC, which is probably a large percentage of PHP web devs. I can honestly say it saved me hours of head scratching and Stack Overflow mining.

results.content:
I ran into this course while searching for a course that could help to understand how PHP MVC frameworks are working, preferably with building a (web app) project at the end. I admit I haven't checked the course outline thoroughly, so when I started with the course, I was a bit surprised with how relatively short lectures are only to realize - there will be no project done here. 
However, now that I completed the course, I don't really regret it. I managed to learn a lot about how MVC framework in PHP is working, how each component "talks" to each other and at the end I have a solid PHP MVC framework I can use to start building web applications. Dave's approach to teaching is something I wish other educators could embrace. For each lecture, you get visual drawings with clear explanation on the matter followed by code presentation and finally webpage example. 
If you are looking for a course to understand PHP MVC framework by building it from scratch, this is the one to take.

Great content for anyone wanting to learn the MVC structure from no knowledge whatsoever. I'm really glad I bought this course, just finished and I am now wiser than I was before. However, it isn't perfect. 

Dave is awesome, speaks in a very enlightful way, but the course has a lot of theory and less practical code. You won't see Dave typing anything with you. Instead, he will just show you the modified code at the end of the lecture and you have to go do it yourself or simply download the update attached version. 

The lectures are short and straight to the point, but lacks details. I would have loved to see a new class being added bringing more interactions with the already existing ones, and bringing a controller that does more than just shows data to the screen.

Thank you for the great content Dave!

response.content:
Hola, gracias por la valoración. Es verdad que en el código fuente pone PHP 5.4 (un error de mi parte poner la versión en un comentario de código así), pero está 100% compatible con la última versión de PHP. El curso pone que está actualizado en 2019 porque ha habido actualizaciones recientes, y aunque hay elementos del curso que no han sido actualizados, lo que sale en la descripción del curso con respecto a la fecha de la última actualización corresponde a la última vez que ha habido un cambio. Sin embargo, el contenido del curso sigue siendo relevante con respecto a los frameworks MVC. Si tienes alguna pregunta sobre ello, no dudes en contactar conmigo.

Un cordial saludo,
Dave

results.content:
Okay, so usually I don't write reviews. But for this course I feel like I should!

When you start a module in this course, the teacher first explains the concepts that will be used in this part of the code. He doesn't take any shortcuts and explains different possibilities, how they function exactly, what the pro's and con's are, and why we will settle on this particular method.

Then he shows you the code (which is also available for download). This is explained in a clear and concise manner, which allows you to fully understand what is happening and why. After a module there is a quiz, which allows you to test if you understand the applied concepts, or if you need to review a certain section a bit more.

From this course, I have learnt precisely how to write PHP in an OOP manner in a MVC paradigm, including advanced routing and using namespaces.
 
Not only do I now fully understand the concepts and considerations when starting such a project, the quality of my code has substantially improved. For example, the way I write comments has changed to provide much more information in fewer lines.

Overall, I would HIGHLY recommend this course for anybody who is not clear on certain aspects of MVC or anyone who is trying to write cleaner code.

Finally, the teacher responds to questions and issues and provides solutions that are easy and work. These are also explained in a thorough manner. The replies to comments or questions are incredibly quick! In certain cases I didn't even have to wait for 5 minutes.

Overall, if you are looking for a course on MVC, this is the one. Period.

results.content_html:
A bit basic and not necessarily correct. Going back to the origins of MVC - SmallTalk - the controller is not the only layer to talk to the model - it's the view as well. i.e.:
request -> controller -> model - sets model to users request
response = view gets requested data from model.
Then immutable models can be utilized:-
$model = new Model();
$controller = new Controller(Model $model);
$model = $controller->setModelDate();
$view = new View($model);
$view->render();
But as 80% of MVC articles do exactly as you do, you can't be blamed
regex examples are very useful

results.content:
This is an excellent course. It needs solid PHP baseline though. 

I really liked the presentation style of Dave and that he provides resources to most sub-sections. There are no time wasters and unnecessary chit-chats during the lessons.

I really liked the experience of using Twig. I did not like template engines so far, because of bad past experiences with them in compiled languages (they needed to be recompiled on code change). But with PHP, at least Twig, worked like a charm.

I played with Yii2 and CakePHP in the past, but did not get through the basics. Now, I think I finally have the missing link to better understand how they work end to end.

I can only recommend this course to take your practical skills to the next level.

I got off to a bit of a rough start by using a Docker LAMP stack instead of AMPPS on Windows. The benefit I got from the training is writing and debugging a *working baseline* MVC framework. So many of the training courses teach how to build a solution looking for a problem. This course got me to develop a template I can apply as the starting point of a web-based AMP solution. Bravo Dave for thinking outside the box
and delivering useful kit.

results.content:
This course on MVC from scratch is full of resources, well explained and I am very impressed.

I picked up a lot of stuff and you explained so cleary. It sounded simple.
I admit I have been reading about and struggled on some of these and this course helped a lot in finding the light.

On a constructive note, we covered Router, Routing, Controller .. and a bit of View tiny tiny, very tiny bits of Models.
In all fairness it was more of an ..vC +RR  course than MVC :-).
It works for me because the router,controller are indeed the area I had been banging my head on, by the way.

But in the models for example you have a "get data" methods only. Would have been nice to see a "add" , "modify" method.
If not all explained in a session at least in the code example, maybe ?


But overall this definitely exceeded my expectations.

Great course ! 
I highly recommend, and many many thanks !


Jean

In all fairness it was more of an ..vC +RR course than MVC :-).
It works for me because the router,controller are indeed the area I had been banging my head on, by the way.

But in the models for example you have a "get data" methods only. Would have been nice to see a "add" , "modify" method.
If not all explained in a session at least in the code example, maybe ?

But overall this definitely exceeded my expectations.

Great course !
I highly recommend, and many many thanks !

Jean

results.content:
Dave is a great knowledgeable tutor, that really helps students and replys quickly to questions even if he pretentiously speaks like a robot...just speak normal man - I have to use 1.5 speed, but the strange pauses and wierd emphasis is jarring! 

I have major issues with unnecessary 3rd party inclusions - seriously change the name of this course, or re-do it in basic PHP. 

I want to know the MVC pattern in pure PHP, even if its just basic 'helloworld' functionality that I can adapt to my own projects, but I did not want to have to install any 3rd party librarys for this, 3rd party templates for that, 3rd party frameworks... blah blah blah.  

I will watch course a second/third time to see if I can pick up the intent and implement it myself in php..running the risk that I make a mess of it because its not explained so good via php, and I am a beginner in both.

However, having tried two different courses for php MVC, this is definitely the most difficult to follow because it incorperates advanced concepts of implementing MVC , but I think in a good way it is done in a very professional manner and the results are very professional after the work and headscratching are over.

I have now incorperated this MVC and taken bits of the other course I thought were neat solutions and added them to this, rather than the other way around.

results.content:
It's a very good course, and the author is clearly very knowledgeable about the MVC structure and the PHP language overall, but the two downsides of the course is that it doesn't take advantage of php 7+, it's using a deprecated version of PHP, even though the code runs on higher versions (so far), the other downside is that the author doesn't write any code, and it's kind of annoying to keep following what he's saying and write the code manually, you'll have to stop every single video multiple times to do that, and the other solution would be to grab the course assets and replace what you already have after every couple of vids and this is also annoying. 
Else than that the course is really good, and you learn a lot if you follow the details, and try to write everything yourself.

response.content:
Thank you for your review and feedback Khalil!

The code is fully compatible with PHP 7, even though it might show another version in some of the videos. I'm planning to publish a major update soon that will take advantage of PHP 7's features.

I don't write code in real time in the videos as I think this takes up too much time, and detracts from the lesson being taught. However I understand that just showing the code changes and explaining them can be difficult to follow sometimes, so I'll be updating the course to show code changes as I make them, in the same style that I show code on the follow-up course to this one.

Thank you again for your feedback, it's most appreciated!

Best wishes,
Dave

results.content:
This is an excellent starter tutorial for the understanding of MVC Frameworks. This is an ideal primer especially if you wish to start another framework like Laravel, Code Igniter etc. 

However having just completed this course I now feel confident to publish my first "MVC " website and see if I really need to invest in learning the larger "Laravel Framework".

The content is well presented with solid explanations and full documentation and code resources at every level.  Whilst the course has been developed, upgraded and kept up to date over the last few years, the next promised update to the "Controllers" section  to remove the _call magic methods is eagerly awaited. It will then be worth a full 5 stars rating.

Mac

results.content: Brillante curso, la mejor inversión que hice en la plataforma. Ideal para aquellos que ya entienden php orientado a objetos pero al ingresar al desarrollo con un framework sienten que les faltan conocimiento. Dave explica paso por paso como desarrollar un sencillo pero potente framework MVC. A diferencia de otros cursos donde el instructor escribe cada linea de código y las lecciones terminan durando 20 minutos, aquí muestra que lineas toca en cada archivo y adjunta el código fuente completo. De esta forma nos invita a comparar nuestro código lección a lección y aprender el proceso de desarrollo. Esto es para mi es lo fundamental. Personalmente todas las dificultades que tuve las pude sortear o por lógica o por leer los comentarios donde Dave detalladamente da soporte a los alumnos. Ya compré el curso siguiente a este para incorporar el login system. 100% recomendado.

I ran into some minor difficulties getting Apache to install/run as a service due to ports 80 & 443 being actively used by IIS which was automatically installed without my knowledge when I upgraded Windows 7 Ultimate to Win 10.  That was fixed by disabling the IIS feature.  I still had some issues with running the code but I believe that was probably a configuration problem.  After reverting to Win 7, and re-installing Apache2.4 and Php 7.0.8  everything seems to be running smoothly.
Dave has put a lot of effort into creating and presenting this class and I'm very grateful.

results.content:
This is a very nice course for anyone not familiar with MVC other than knowing what the letters stand for. I do find the pace to be a bit slow, but on the upside that's one of the things that makes this very thorough. As an experienced PHP developer however, I had to fast forward and skip ahead a lot. I only took this course to learn more about how MVC framworks are built and used, as that's something I've never used before, but since it's so popular I figured there must be a reason for that.

Oh, and I learned about namespaces, which was new to me. I've been a procedural fellow for many years, and have only recently moved to the object oriented world, so namespaces was still murky waters, up until now. I've read briefly about them before, but after taking this course they finally make sense.

Essentially, the only negative experience I have with this course is due only to the fact that I am perhaps a bit outside of the target audience, and that's hardly the fault of the course :)

results.content:
This course is EXACTLY what I was looking for. I've been writing PHP for about a year now, and it's always felt really unorganized. I've always felt like I was just "doing it wrong." 

Dave's explanations are clear and concise. He's straight to the point and doesn't fluff up his lectures with anything unnecessary.

My only complaint is that he doesn't do any live coding, but rather shows us completed code. It would be much more helpful (but more time-consuming) to explain the code as it's being written, and to show live mistakes.

One last thing - take this course more than once. There's only about 3 hours of content, but every second is very important, so you're not going to be able to obtain it all at once. Each lecture is super short, so it's really not a big deal to watch them twice or even three times!

results.content:
Dave did an exceptional job in this course. The "router" setup and configuration exceeded my expectations! The regex explanation went deep and was really enlightering.
The course as whole is friendly and well explained.

That said, I would recommend him to pay more attention to the "model" part of this course. I think there is more to say (and do) about it. But it was concise and served as an introduction to this section in the MVC standards.

In summary, this course is worthy it's price and will help anyone willing to understand or build a rich MVC featured framework.

response.content:
Thank you very much for your kind review and detailed feedback Richard! I appreciate the feedback - is there anything specific you would like to see included about the model part?

I am planning a major course update next year, and I'll be including more example code, including models. Detailed examples of how models work in a login system are covered in the follow-up course, "Build a Complete Registration and Login System using PHP MVC".

Thank you again for your feedback, I really appreciate it!

Best wishes,
Dave

response.content:
Dear Marco,

thank you for taking the time out to leave a review. I really appreciate the feedback. I'm sorry you didn't have a great experience with the course. The regular expressions section is long because it's quite a complex part of the course - the routing part of MVC is very complicated and I think it needs a lot of material to explain it clearly.

As for writing your own code, I understand your concerns, and although I do mention at the start of the course that the best way to get the most out of the course is to follow along with the code yourself, I appreciate that there could be more interactivity. I plan to update the course in the near future to reflect this, so I hope that improves your opinion of the course.

In the meantime, if there's anything specific that I can help you with, please don't hesitate to ask.

Thank you again for taking the time out to send feedback, I really appreciate it.

Best wishes,
Dave

results.content: At first I thought that the slow pace will bother me, but that turned out to be exactly what I needed. I did not finish the course yet, but at the beginning you can see that Dave is using PHP 5.x.x - I just want to say that I had no trouble following with PHP 7.x.x. Also, regular expressions section was very helpful and very well explained.

results.content: Dave Hollingworth does an excellent job describing the inner working of his code. This course would be worth the price of admission for the excellent sections on regular expressions and namespaces alone. His finely detailed, yet accessible descriptions and explanations are some of the best I've seen. I'm docking a half star only, because I would personally prefer that the code be typed live. I learn better this way, as it allows me to watch, pause, and type the code myself. The ability to debug and find my own typos is part of the learning process. This course does an EXCELLENT job of describing the code and the theory behind it, but then simply shows the completed code and a download link is provided. I'm still learning tons, but I wish Dave had typed the code live, even if it made the course twice as long. Still, Dave is obviously tremendously talented and knowledgeable. Top notch instructor and course.

response.content:

I use this method in the follow-up course to this one. I hope that will be helpful!

Thanks again for the detailed feedback, I really appreciate it!

Cheers,
Dave

results.content:
Great course! I love how it's short and laser focused. I also got the user authorization course that uses the same framework, (They were bundled together.) it's also well constructed and gets right to the point.

I've liked PHP for a while now, but the path based meta of http seemed wrong. This cleans that up nicely and allows really elegant and simple design. I don't particularly like the overly  syntactic approach of some of the OOP, so I'm toning that down into more of a "less-OOP PHP" system. And I think that's going to work really well for me.

I did have a problem with the "pretty urls" mechanic, mostly, I think, because I'm running Ubuntu linux and just running all the tools (Apache2, PHP, MySQL) directly as if I was on a server (Using the apache VirtualHost through etc/apache2/sites-available) instead of using a virtual box setup like XAMPP or whatnot. But the routing all works, so it does what it needs to do. And it's fast.

response.content:
Dear Nguyen,

thank you for taking the time out to leave a review. I'm sorry you didn't enjoy the course. Please let me try and address your concerns below.

Perhaps you are right that the title could be misinterpreted if maybe you were looking for a course on how to program PHP from scratch. However, it is clearly stated in the description and course pre-requisites that the course is not for beginners to PHP and some PHP knowledge is required to complete the course. I do think though that it is suitable for all levels of those looking to understand MVC from a practical standpoint, as at each stage any new concept is explained in detail. I will however go over the course description to make sure I clarify anything that could be ambiguous.

To get the most out of the course, the code shown and explained in detail in the videos that is attached to each lecture should be downloaded and experimented with on your own server. That's why at the beginning of the course I encourage you to get your own web server up and running so you can follow along with the code. I understand you might prefer more exercises where you have to type code, and I'll certainly look into whether adding this is suitable fit for the course.

I respectfully disagree that the course lacks code explanations and is just slides, as the videos that are explanatory slides, which explain a concept, that also include code are followed by an explanation of the code, shown in an editor, file by file, with detailed explanation of the code. As I say to all my students, I'm very happy to explain anything in detail that isn't already included in the course if you need it. Many of the other students on this course have taken me up on this offer and the course has many 5-star reviews.

Again I'm sorry the course wasn't what you expected, and I fully understand if you want to get a refund. Thank you for finishing the course and for writing such a detailed review, I really do appreciate the feedback.

Best wishes,
Dave

results.content:
This course was a revelation for me.  Prior to starting it, I'd gotten fairly competent with object-oriented PHP, but my code was still poorly organized.  And because it wasn't following an MVC framework, there were security gaps in my website that I wasn't happy with.

Learning an MVC framework can be quite tricky at first, but Dave is an incredible teacher.  He thoughtfully and carefully breaks down each topic into its component concepts and examples.  And he provides incredibly robust coding solutions that other Udemy teachers shy away from (such as his deep dive into the flexibility of regular expression named capture groups to handle URL routing).  

And on top of all of that, he is amazingly attentive and responsive to students' questions, often submitting a working and detailed coding solution within 24-48 hours.  With other Udemy teachers, literal months can go by without an answer to questions that I've submitted.  When you're attempting to learn a topic as complex as MVC coding frameworks, that attention and care toward students is more valuable than gold.

Long story short, Dave has quickly become my top instructor to learn from on Udemy.  I've already purchased other courses of his, and plan to remain one of his students for as long as he produces content.  Can't speak highly enough about both this course and Dave as a teacher.

response.content:
Hi Uzoma,

thank you very much for your review! I'm sorry the course doesn't use your preferred method for showing code. In fact, I actually try to avoid typing too much code in lectures as it takes a lot of time and distracts from the point I'm trying to teach, which is why I show the code changes already written but then explain what's been changed.

However  I do understand that writing code "live" is a good way to see how coding is done sometimes, so as long as it doesn't take attention away from the subject of the video and doesn't affect the length in a negative way, I'll consider adding some typed code into future videos.

Thank you again for your feedback, I really do appreciate it!

Best wishes,
Dave

results.content:
There is just one word to define Dave’s MVC course: “SUBLIME”.
First of all his english is music to my ears. I am not an english native and only God knows how much those like me need good english to understand difficult technical contents. Sometimes this is one of the drawbacks of Udemy courses. When it comes to technical asides excellent english is a must.
The course is well paced. If you are an expert you can skip some parts easily. If you are a beginner you need to watch all videos. In my opinion there is a perfect balance between speed and technicality.
Dave’s slides are clear and concise: a good companion to help you memorize difficult topics.
This course is useful to those who want to understand MVC paradigm and move on to frameworks like Lumen/Laravel, Slim etc.
You do not need to be a Master in PHP to understand everything. Dave takes you gradually from simple to difficult concepts and at the end of the entire course you will have the feeling that nothing has been left behind.
Definetly this course is worth the money I spent and I would recomend it to my colleagues and anyone who wants to understand how any PHP MVC framework works .
This is not "one of the many" courses around about MVC with PHP. This is "the" MVC PHP course everybody should take especially if coming from procedural programming and want to understand how a MVC frameworks like Laravel/Lumen, Slim work.
If I could I would rate this course 6 STARS.

results.content:
An absolutely exceptional (pun intended) course regarding MVC frameworks. In this course you will learn much about MVC, it is perfect for all levels from beginners to more advanced devs looking to revise or practice. Dave is one of the most thorough, concise, and helpful tutors I have had the pleasure of learning from, he is quick to answer questions and takes the time to respond sufficiently.

Everything in this course is covered from an Object Oriented perspective, this is one of the few MVC framework courses I have found which actually uses OOP throughout rather than procedural PHP. 

Even if you have covered this before (as I have) you will benefit from a greater understanding achieved by undertaking this course. The advanced routing was especially sufficient as it helped me to understand building routing engine in an object oriented manner, rather than simply parsing URLs through a single functional PHP script. 

Dave also covers error handling, exception handling, logging etc... in enough detail to at least get you well on your way. I wish I had found this course back when I had first been learning MVC.

results.content_html:
An absolutely exceptional (pun intended) course regarding MVC frameworks. In this course you will learn much about MVC, it is perfect for all levels from beginners to more advanced devs looking to revise or practice. Dave is one of the most thorough, concise, and helpful tutors I have had the pleasure of learning from, he is quick to answer questions and takes the time to respond sufficiently.

Everything in this course is covered from an Object Oriented perspective, this is one of the few MVC framework courses I have found which actually uses OOP throughout rather than procedural PHP.

Even if you have covered this before (as I have) you will benefit from a greater understanding achieved by undertaking this course. The advanced routing was especially sufficient as it helped me to understand building routing engine in an object oriented manner, rather than simply parsing URLs through a single functional PHP script.

Dave also covers error handling, exception handling, logging etc... in enough detail to at least get you well on your way. I wish I had found this course back when I had first been learning MVC.

results.content:
Amazing from start to finish. I came hoping to improve my understanding of MVC architecture. MISSION ACCOMPLISHED! I would have paid the full price just for the lessons on routing alone! Furthermore, I've also drastically improved in other areas of programming in which I was dreadfully inept (looking at you regex). Excellent course. 

If you're interested in developing your own MVC framework and tired of hearing everyone on Stack Overflow telling you "You need to choose an existing framework" and "Don't reinvent the wheel" and sick of wading through all of the dogma, elitism and B.S. endemic to sites like that, then take this course.

I will say, I've only been developing using OO PHP for about 1.5 years now and there were times that I really had to try hard to understand what was going on. I feel like I have the bare minimum required knowledge and experience to complete this course. Please read the instructor's requirements for this course and don't take it if you can't meet them.

Final Words: 5 STARS - TAKE THIS COURSE!

results.content:
This was an older course... but was still very relevant! I highly recommend this course if you want to understand MVCs. This course is a really, really good way to learn about MVC. Excellent instruction. Thank you!

Having said that, one thing was just annoying, the inclusion of a template halfway through the course. I found that to be a distracting addition that was not really on topic of the course. I'm not saying templates aren't relevant, but I really think adding one could have been done in a "bonus" chapter at the end of the course, since there are a number of code changes to be made. I'm glad it was covered, but really feel like it was in the wrong place.

Beyond that, a couple things I would have preferred... 

1. a typealong is always easier to follow. but with so much content I understand why the pages were pre-typed and just explained with a 'walk through'...
2. The twig 'installation' isn't so cut and dry. I ended up taking the zip file included with the lecture and copy/pasting the install on to my folder structure. Not ideal, nor realistic. That part was disappointing.
3. The editor used doesn't highlight what directory the open file is in on the sidebar. So, be very careful of the file you are changing or creating. There are redundant files in the directory tree.
4. Not having a type-along means the student has to stop, type, back up catch a minor change in something else, infer things, and then hope the page renders or start the entire video again. Not ideal.

Despite these points, this is the best MVC course I've studied. And I appreciate the instructors style, explanations and work. I'll look for more courses from him in the future.

response.content: Thank you very much for your review and detailed feedback Paul. I'm working on a course update right now that will address the issues that you raise: I'll be introducing code as it's added rather than explaining already added code; Twig will be moved to later on in the course; and I'll make sure the folder is highlighted so that it's obvious which file is being edited. I'll keep you updated as to when the updated version is available! Many thanks again for your detailed feedback, it's most appreciated!

results.content:
Course delivers what it promises.  Course clearly explains how to create a custom Model-View-Controller (MVC) PHP framework from scratch.   In the process, Object Oriented PHP is illustrated.   The course is well organized, and claims to be complete although I am not qualified to compare the safety and efficiency of the resulting custom MVC framework to other frameworks like Laravel or Slim (mentioned in the last lecture).   

Some obvious course design choices were made to keep the course concise.  One of these was the frequent introduction of pre-written code with a brief comment to the effect "We do it like this..."  followed by a few seconds screen time showing the resulting code.  In other words, this is not a 'type-along-with-me" type of course, and I have to trust that the provided code will be the same as that shown and be as clear as the course itself.    I mention this because some other Udemy courses actually create the code, on-the-fly, testing it in segments before your eyes, and this inevitably generates a few errors which create a learning opportunity in how things work.  This course is not designed that way but is probably an equally valid way of presenting the information efficiently.

The instructor uses AMPPS rather than XAMPP stack, yet appears to be quite Linux friendly.   I had some minor concerns with the installation process on Linux (such as how to properly secure the development server) and I eventually decided to just use Cloud 9 online PHP development environment instead,   The author does offer a discount on his other course that claims to cover the web development environment installation process in detail.  I have not taken that course and probably will not because $10 seems to be a bit pricey for such basic (although important) information.  I'm sure I can find that info elsewhere for free, and that it will become outdated quickly.

response.content:
Thank you so much for your detailed feedback and kind review Dell, I really appreciate it! You're right, I made the conscious decision to not "type as you code" as I think that although that type of teaching has its place, it can be inefficient for showing large code changes, and detracts from the lesson being taught.

As for AMPPS, I plan to update the course in the near future to use XAMPP, as it's easier to use. They're mostly compatible though and the code and techniques shown on the course are compatible with XAMPP.

The web development environment course covers many things about how to configure a web development environment on your computer, from virtual hosts and local web addresses to setting up databases and even installing a third-party package like WordPress.

If you have any questions about deployment or any other topic, please don't hesitate to ask, I'm happy to help.

Thank you again for your feedback, I really appreciate it!

Best wishes,
Dave

results.content:
Even though PHP version 5.4 is used, till now there are no deprecated features used. Classes are very compact, the teacher simply goes over his already written code and describes what is happening. However, it requires a lot of research yourself and continuously examining your own code. What's happening, what does this function mean, what does that RegEx expression means? If you approach this course like that, it's definitely worth its money. If you're more of a person who wants to be taken by the hand, look for a different course as this one wouldn't suit your needs. 

If he talked a little bit faster and wrote the code in the class with you; this course would've earned 5 stars. But it definitely helped me build a better understanding of what actually happens behind the scenes in popular frameworks like Laravel and how to think like a programmer.

It's very well organized, and rich with valuable information and insight, making it an excellent reference to return to again and again.

results.content: This has been a fantastic course. Really great experience. I highly recommend any developer who wants to advance themselves with PHP development to take this course. It covers lots of advanced aspects. It's fascinating to see the development of the MVC framework from scratch, and understand the mechanics of how it all works. There is so much value to gain from this experience. Thank you Dave for such a great course. I will shortly be moving on and purchasing your other courses as well.

results.content:
In today's world most of the people directly jump towards learning something and we are exposed to variety of tutorials, but to be honest all that is required initially is "why we do what we do" and I am thankful that i came across Dave's Course. How beautifully he exposed the MVC architecture and guided us to built one is simply amazing. Though, he did not code a single line, but he did his job of explaining things. So anyone out there who wants to experience this beautifully presented course and want to understand what an MVC is, then this course is for you. 

I hope that Dave had a course on laravel too. I would have surely loved his explanation. In the meanwhile, I guess I have to search for a laravel course that would match Dave's way of explaining things.

Thank You! Dave. Thanks a lot.

results.content:
It's definitely a good start for a new bee (new to MVC, with basic knowledge on PDO, OOP, PHP). He got very good teaching skills, lectures are delivered slowly and clearly , easy to understand. Presentations are clear. Overall it's a simply explained nice course. And he will respond to your problems quickly with well explained answers.
I wish if he adds few more actions to the post model (add, view, edit, delete posts) enabling deeper understanding about the use of models and the overall MVC, that will be really helpful.

Update:
By reading my review he was kind enough to sent me an UPDATED source code  y adding new functions to the model (add, view, update and delete). I really appreciate his kindness and helpfulness towards his students. I thank him and highly recommend this course for new students.
